subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
The Middle and Old Chinese reconstruction of this word is phonologically problematic ({{zh-ref|STEDT}}):
* {{zh-ref|Karlgren (1957)}} notes that the Middle Chinese form is irregular based on evidence from ''{{w|Shijing}}'' rimes.
* Based on velar contacts in the same phonetic series, e.g. {{zh-l|*巛}}, {{zh-l|*甽}} and {{zh-l|*訓}}, {{zh-ref|Baxter (1992)}} and {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} reconstruct the word with a velar initial ({{zh-ref|Handel, 1998}}; {{zh-ref|Sagart, 1999}}), which undergoes irregular palatalization in the development to Middle Chinese ({{zh-ref|Baxter, 1992}}).
* Based on other characters in the same phonetic series, e.g. {{zh-l|*順}} and {{zh-l|*馴}}, {{zh-ref|Sagart (1999)}}, and later, {{zh-ref|Baxter and Sagart (2014)}}, reconstructs {{lang|zh|川}} with a lateral initial and suggests that only a ''*t-'' prefix would account for the Middle Chinese initial {{IPAchar|/t͡ɕʰ/}}.

{{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} relates this word to {{cog|sit-pro|*kl(j)u(ŋ/k)||river; valley}}, whence {{och-l|江|river}}, {{och-l|谷|valley|id=2}}, {{cog|bo|ཀླུང||river}}, {{cog|my|ချောင်း||stream}}. {{zh-ref|STEDT}} notes that this does not account for the ''*-n'' coda.

{{zh-ref|STEDT}} instead compares it to {{cog|sit-pro|*m-t(w)əj-n ~ *m-ti-s||water; fluid; liquid; river; soak; spit}}, whence {{och-l|涕|tears|id=1}}, {{cog|tbq-kuk-pro|*tuj||water; fluid; liquid}}, {{cog|cdm|तीः||water; rain; river}}; this depends on a reconstruction with a dental initial and requires positing an ''*‑n'' suffix not present in Tibeto-Burman languages.
